titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Nancie Abbie Harriman papers, 1861-1865
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, November 2021

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.abstract: Primarily letters addressed to Nancie A. Harriman from Willie Byrd Stevens, a soldier in the 4th Vermont Infantry, 1861-1864. While he was in service in Virginia and Maryland, he was located in Fairfax Co., Yorktown, Aquia Creek, Culpepper, and Port Royal in Virginia and in Annapolis, Maryland. The letters and information filed with the collection indicate Stevens was imprisoned in Richmond, Va. for approximately six months in late 1863 and early 1864, and died after suffering wounds in the battle at Cold Harbor, Va., in June 1864. The collection also includes one poem.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: Nancie Abbie Harriman Papers, 1861-1865, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, November 2021.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Primarily letters addressed to Nancie A. Harriman from Willie Byrd Stevens, a soldier in the 4th Vermont Infantry, 1861-1864. While he was in service in Virginia and Maryland, he was located in Fairfax Co., Yorktown, Aquia Creek, Culpepper, and Port Royal in Virginia and in Annapolis, Maryland. The letters and information filed with the collection indicate Stevens was imprisoned in Richmond, Va. for approximately six months in late 1863 and early 1864, and died after suffering wounds in the battle at Cold Harbor, Va., in June 1864. The collection also includes one poem.
